intro: Buchnera pilosa var. arizonica, commonly known as the Arizona hairy bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the southwestern United States. It features hairy, glandular stems and leaves, which are characteristic of the Boraginaceae family. The plant produces showy, blue to violet flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Its botanical structure supports its adaptation to arid environments, making it a resilient species in its native range.
